docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Several years ago, when regulations of the Food and Drug Administration were being tightened, some food industry officials complained that they might soon need special permission from the Government to put mustard on a frankfurter.

headline.main: Food; Fresh Look at What Is and Is Not Safe to Eat

docs.abstract: some of ramifications of ban discussed; cartoon
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON -- Several years ago, when regulations of the Food and Drug Administration were being tightened, some food industry officials complained that they might soon need special permission from the Government to put mustard on a frankfurter.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A scientist in St. Louis said today that he had fed infant mice monosodium glutamate in amounts greater than those in baby food and had produced brain damage in the portions of the mice's brains regulating appetite.

headline.main: Doses of Monosodium Glutamate Found to Affect Brains of Mice; Tests Find Monosodium Glutamate Affects Mice

docs.abstract: Prof J W Olney and Prof J Mayer urge that monosodium glutamate be removed from baby foods after Olney's findings that large doses of it caused brain damage in infant mice and monkeys; H J Heinz gen mgr Hutchings and Gerber Products chief exec Gerber doubt that Olney's research is applicable to man; Olney's experiments described
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A scientist in St. Louis said today that he had fed infant mice monosodium glutamate in amounts greater than those in baby food and had produced brain damage in the portions of the mice's brains regulating appetite.

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.Special to The New York Times
